Expectation1: Be considerate with shared spaces and boundaries
Situation1: My dog becomes vocal in the hallway when people pass near shared doors.
Expectation2: Arrive at the polling station during designated voting hours
Situation2: Polls stay open all day and the voter has a light schedule.
Story:
This morning, I was getting ready to take my dog out for a quick walk before heading to the polling station. As a neighbor, I always try to be considerate—our building’s walls are thin, and my dog, Max, has a habit of barking loudly whenever someone passes by our shared hallway. I know it annoys Mrs. Patel next door, who works nights and sleeps during the day. I usually time our walks to avoid the busiest hours, but today is election day, and I promised myself I’d vote early. The polls are open all day, and my schedule is light, but I feel a responsibility to get there promptly, to set a good example and fulfill my civic duty.

As I clip on Max’s leash, I hear footsteps outside. If I wait, I’ll be late for my planned voting time. If I go now, Max will almost certainly bark and disturb the neighbors. My stomach knots as I stand by the door, torn between being a good neighbor and a responsible voter, feeling the weight of both expectations pressing in on me.
